title: Why Class Bias in Arts Jobs Should Be Against the Law
summary: A new report says that treating people unfairly because they are from a working-class background should be illegal, especially in jobs like acting, music, and art. The report talked to over 300 people who work in creative jobs in places like Greater Manchester. Many of them said they faced bullying or bias because of where they came from, like being laughed at for their accent or not having enough money. Some people were not paid fairly for their work, and others had to take extra jobs to survive. The report wants the government to make class a protected characteristic, like age or gender, so everyone has a fair chance. Famous people like James Graham and Jason Manford support this idea to help working-class creatives succeed.

background_read: This article is about a report that looks at how people from working-class backgrounds are treated in creative jobs like acting or music. It explains that many face unfair treatment, such as not being paid or being bullied for their accent. The report suggests making class a protected characteristic to help stop this discrimination and give everyone equal opportunities in the arts.
Article_Structure: WHO: Working-class people in creative jobs, James Graham, Jason Manford, and Nazir Afzal.
WHAT: A report says class bias should be illegal because many face harassment and unfair pay in arts jobs.
WHERE: Mainly in Greater Manchester, England.
WHY: To make opportunities fairer and stop discrimination against working-class creatives.

perspectives.description: The report and supporters believe making class a protected characteristic will reduce bias and help working-class people succeed in creative industries.
